page.lettertext:
fol.207r
Belgia [bis] 1594 6 June
Maye it please your H. to be advertised
at I receaved your l
re
s
of
e 24 of
e last,
e second of this present, and letter therein
inclosed from her
Hig
es
to
e
States
which I delivered to
em
e
next daye after, and they promised to aunswer, when according
to their custome, they shall have taken some tyme to deliberat
upon it. How they have agreed to satisfie her Ma
tie
for
e
points of my Instructions I have formerlie signified to my L. T
re
r
and sent their owne letter to
e self same effect, having noe other
cause to remayne at
e Haghe, but onelie to attend her Hig
es
further pleasure. In the meane while I doe not ceasse to solli-
cit
e chiefest of
e Deputies, both to call upon
e Provinces, to
arme as many shippes as conveniently they maye, and to returne
their aunswear hither assoone as is possible. I have
alsoe written to Co. Maurice to
e very same purpose, and reque-
sted
S
r
Francis Vere
to urge him to it very earnestly. I am
informed at this instant
at there are Hoyes sent to
Flushing
for embarking
e companies, for which I thincke it very requisit
to call for those supplies which they have promised heere, and will
perfourme I doe not doubt assoone as shalbe needfull.
Although I know
at
M
r
Gilpin
doth keepe his course in reporting
all other occurrences, yet unwilling
at my l
re
should come emptie
to your H. I can not but advertise
at heere is very great hope
of
e taking of
Groeninghen,
partlie by reason they are divided
among themselves, and partlie for
at they can hardlie be relieved
with further succors from
e Enemie, by meanes of our forces which
laye upon
e passages. Nevertheles they doe not shew any token in
e course of their defence,
at they will give it over hastilie.
For they shoote very thicke, and make manie sallies, and put us
often to
e worse, and in
at respect
e English have had their
parte aswell as others, besydes
at manie fall sicke of
e Companies
lastly levyed. We have certaine intelligence
at
e Duke du
Mayne having bin at
Bruxelles
with
Ernestus
for 2 or 3 dayes
is departed from thence with letters of Exchange for 80000
Ducats, and with assurance by promis to be further assisted, both
with horse and foote, which are gathering in great nombers with
all expedition.
Verdugo
as wee heare hath sent alredy into
France
700 horse in liew of which it should seeme by letters from
Andwerpe,
Ernestus is mynded to send his spaniards into
Friseland
fol.207v
which is alsoe thought
e rather, for
at
e Spaniards are not welcome
to
e
Co. Charles Mansfelt
. The Count it is written ha-
ving left la chapelle, is come as farre as
Guise,
and advaunceth
his Armie towardes
e
Kinge,
who we saye at this present besiegeth
Laon,
and is soe farre engaged, as he ca
n
ot with hys ho
n
or but
attend
e others coming, which hath raised heere with us a great
expectation of the event of their meeting.
In effect this all
at of
e speeches heere with us I fynde worth
e writinge
For which I take my humble leave.
From the Haghe June 6
1594
